facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCriminal Appeal No. 50 of 1957. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 27, 1956 of Rajasthan High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954 arising out

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated March 23, 1954 of Sessions Judge at Ganganagar in Original Criminal Case No. 74 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 23, 1954, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ganganagar in Original Criminal Case No. 74 of 1953. Mohan Behari Lal,

facts.text: Bhagwandas, Netram and Mt. Rameshwari tried by Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for offence under s. 302 IPC and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former, were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for an offence under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted under s.302 read with s.34, sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were convicted under s.302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.

anchor.surface_text: The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted.

facts.text: Canal after temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953. And although it was not his turn of water the deceased Shivlal

facts.text: Shivlal was allowed to take water to irrigate his fields on May 5, 1953 though not his turn.

anchor.surface_text: And although it was not his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields.

facts.text: On May 6, 1953 canal flowing full capacity, Shivlal's turn 6 hours from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On May 6 the canal was flowing to its full capacity and Shivlal was to take his turn of water which was of 6 hours duration from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

facts.text: Shivlal watered lands from 8 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. on May 6 to fill village diggi.

anchor.surface_text: but he watered his lands from 8 a.m. to 10-30 a.m. because the village diggi pond which was empty had to be filled up.

facts.text: Mirab Ram Karan PW1 with consent of Shivlal diverted water to fill diggi, promising rest of turn after.

anchor.surface_text: Mirab Ram Karan P. W. 1 with the consent of Shivlal diverted the water for the purpose of filling up the diggi, promising him Shivlal to get him the rest of his turn of water, i.e., for 3-1/2 hours after the diggi had been filled up.

facts.text: Diggi filled up by 1 p.m. on May 7, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The diggi was filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th.

facts.text: Bhagwandas prevented Shivlal from diverting water to his field, claiming the turn as his.

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal then wanted to divert the water into his field but Bhagwandas prevented him from doing so claiming the turn to be his.

facts.text: According to Ram Karan Mirab PW1, Bhagwandas turn after Surta whose turn after Shivlal.

anchor.surface_text: According to Ram Karan Mirab P. W. I the turn of Bhagwandas was after Surta whose turn was next to that of Shivlal.

facts.text: Bhagwandas hit Shivlal on head with kassi after shouting enemy going.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas thereupon shouted that the enemy was going and hit Shivlal on the head with a kassi.

facts.text: Netram hit Shivlal with lathi, both beat him, Mt. Rameshwari joined with wooden handle of kassi.

anchor.surface_text: Netram then hit Shivlal with lathi as a result of which he fell down and then both beat Shivlal, and Mt. Rameshwari also, it was alleged, joined in this beating with a wooden handle of a kassi.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Hazari PW3 grazing camels in field of Surta.

anchor.surface_text: This occurrence was witnessed by Hazari P. W. 3 who was grazing his camels in the field of Surta.

facts.text: Shivlal died on May 8, 1953 at 8:15 a.m. in hospital.

anchor.surface_text: At the hospital he was treated by the doctor P. W. I I but died the following day 8th at 8-15 a. m.

facts.text: First Information Report recorded on May 7, 1953 at 7:30 p.m. based on report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s/o Shivlal.

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report was based on a written report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s o Shivlal. It was recorded on May 7 at about 7-30 p. m.

facts.text: Shivlal had 15 injuries, injury No.1 sharp-edged, No.2 blunt, both grievous and fatal.

anchor.surface_text: According to the doctors evidence Shivlal was unconscious when he was brought to the hospital at 5 p. m, He had 15 injuries on his body, out of which injury No. 1 was with a sharp-edged weapon and injury No. 2 with a blunt weapon and both these injuries were grievous and were individually and collectively fatal sufficient to cause death.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted accused on March 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge disbelieved the whole evidence and acquitted the accused.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard and judgment on April 2, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957 April 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-

facts.text: Bhagwandas and Netram are brothers, Mt. Rameshwari daughter of Bhagwandas.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former,

facts.text: Kassi recovered but not proved to belong to Bhagwandas.

anchor.surface_text: The recovery of the kassi is a wholly neutral circumstance because it has not been proved that it belonged to Bhagwandas.

On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were convicted under s.302 read with s. 34 and sentenced
they were convicted under s.302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life. The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted.

arguments.court_reasoning: All pieces unreliable or insufficient cumulatively

holdings.text: Hazari's testimony is unreliable due to material detraction from reliability by admitting coaching to mention Begaram and further diminished by acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.

anchor.surface_text: If as observed by the learned Judges of the High Court, Hazari had mentioned the presence of Bega merely because the latter was to be produced as a prosecution witness and because he  Hazari  had been asked to mention it, then it would detract so materially from his reliability that it would be dangerous to accept his testimony as being of any great value which is still more diminished by the finding as to the innocence of Mt. Rameshwari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court noted fabrication regarding Begaram's presence, materially affecting credibility; corroborated by separate acquittal of third accused.

holdings.text: Dying declarations cannot form a sure foundation for conviction when sole eyewitness is disregarded, and ordinarily insufficient alone for murder conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The other piece of evidence which the prosecution relied upon was the two dying declarations made by Shivlal to Gyaniram P. W. 4 and Jora P. W. 7. Besides the infirmities which the testimony of these two witnesses  Gyaniram P. W. 4 and Jora P. W. 1  suffered from due to material contradictions in their respective statements made at various stages of the case and which have been pointed out by the learned Sessions Judge who said about Gyaniram In such a state of affairs I refuse to put any weight and value to the statement of Gyaniram their evidence cannot be a sure foundation for maintaining the conviction if the statement of Hazari the sole eye witness is disregarded, as it must be disregarded in this case because ordinarily a dying declaration of the kind which the prosecution has relied upon is by itself insufficient for sustaining a conviction on a charge of murder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Infirmities and contradictions in declarations; medical evidence of unconsciousness; general rule on insufficiency without corroboration.

holdings.text: High Court erred in rejecting doctor's evidence by relying on medical jurisprudence books without putting relevant passages to the expert witness.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court disposed of this matter by saying that the doctor was comparatively young and that his statement was not in accord with the opinion expressed in books on Medical Jurisprudence by authors like Modi and Lyon. But it cannot be said that the opinions of these authors were given in regard to circumstances exactly similar to those which arose in the case nor before us nor is this a satisfactory way of disposing of the evidence of an expert unless, the passages which are sought to discredit his opinion are put to him. This Court in Sundarlal v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1  disapproved of Judges drawing conclusions adverse to the accused by relying upon such passages in the absence of their being put to medical witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Sundarlal v. State of MP; procedural fairness requires confronting witness with contradictory texts.

holdings.text: Recovery of kassi is a wholly neutral circumstance as not proved to belong to Bhagwandas.

anchor.surface_text: The recovery of the kassi is a wholly neutral circumstance because it has not been proved that it belonged to Bhagwandas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of linkage to accused renders it probative neutral.

holdings.text: Evidence as a whole such that no tribunal could legitimately infer guilt of the accused.

anchor.surface_text: Although this Court will not interfere with the findings of the High Court because its conclusions on the evidence as to the guilt or innocence of the accused differ from that of the High Court, yet where the evidence is such that no Tribunal could legitimately infer from it that the accused is guilty this Court would set aside the conviction. ... In our view the evidence in the present case is of such quality and no legitimate inference of guilt of the accused could properly be drawn.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative assessment of unreliable eyewitness, infirm declarations, neutral recovery, medical improbabilities; follows Stephen Seneviratne precedent.

holdings.text: High Court judgment does not disclose substantial and compelling reasons justifying reversal of trial court's acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so. Surajpal Singh v. State Ajmer Singh v. The State of Punjab  3  Aher Raja Khima v. The State of Saurastra  4 . The judgment of the High Court does not disclose any such reasons justifying interference with the findings of the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established precedents requiring substantial reasons for appellate reversal of acquittal; High Court fails to articulate them.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court disposed of this matter by saying that the doctor was comparatively young and that his statement was not in accord with the opinion expressed in books on Medical Jurisprudence by authors like Modi and Lyon. But it cannot be said that the opinions of these authors were given in regard to circumstances exactly similar to those which arose in the case nor before us nor is this a satisfactory way of disposing of the evidence of an expert unless, the passages which are sought to discredit his opinion are put to him.
